availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: Proof sheet of "Old Age Echoes" with many corrections written in ink and pencil. "Old Age Echoes" is a general heading for four poems: "Sounds of the Winter," "The Unexpress'd," "Sail Out for Good, Eidólon Yacht!," and "After the Argument."

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt

a piece "sail out for good"&c to make a flush page
Let me have another proof without fail

Corrector
Please return proof as soon as possible

remember youth's companion has "Ship Ahoy"
" Scribner has the page cluster

lg.head: SOUND‸S/ OF THE WINTER.
lg.l: SOUNDS of the winter too,
Sunchine upon the mountains—many a distant strain
From cheery railroad train—from nearer field, barn, house,
The whispering air—even the mute crops, garner'd apples, corn,
Children's and women's tones—rhythm of many a farmer ‸, and of flail,

An old man's garrulous lips among the rest.—/ Think not we give out
yet,

l.hi: Forth from these smowy hairs we too keep up the lilt.

lg.head: THE UNEXPRESS'D.
lg.l: How dare one say it?
After the cycles, poems, singers, plays,

Vaunted Ionia's, India's—Homer, Shakespeare—the long, long times'
think dotted roads, areas৩,

The shining clusters and the Milky Ways of stars—Nature's pulses
reap'd.,/
All retrospective passions, heros, war, love, adoration,
All ages' plummets dropt to their utmost depths,
All human lives, throats, wishes, brains—all experiences' utterance‸;
After the countless songs, or long or short, all tongues, all lands,
Still something not yet told in posey's voice or print—something lacking,
(Who knows? the best yet unexpress'd and lacking).

lg.head: Sail out for good, Eidólon Yacht!
lg.l: Heave the anchor short!
Raise main-sail and jib—steer forth,
O little white-hull'd sloop, now speed on really deep waters,
(I will not call it our concluding voyage,
But outset and sure entrance to the truest, best, maturest;)

Depart, depart from solid earth—no more returning to these
shores,
Now on for aye our infinite free venture wending,
Spurning all yet tried ports, seas, hawsers, densities, gravitation,
Sail out for good, eidólon yacht of me!

lg.head: AFTER THE ARGUMENT.
lg.l: A group of ‸little‸ children with their ways and chatter flow in,
Like welcome rippling water o'er my heated nerves and flesh.
